function: String for blas function eg: “getrf”

class hyperlearn.base.lapack(function, numba=None, turbo=True)[source]¶

Bases: object

[Added 14/11/2018] Get a LAPACK function based on the dtype(X). Acts like Scipy’s get lapack function.

function: String for lapack function eg: “getrf” turbo: Boolean to indicate if float32 can be used. numba: String for numba function.

hyperlearn.base.memory(shape, dtype, memcheck)[source]¶

[Edited 18/11/2018 Slightly faster] Checks if an operation on a matrix is within memory bounds.

X: Input matrix dtype: Input datatype(matrix) memcheck: lambda n,p: ... function or f(n,p)

need: Total memory required for operation surplus: Boolean - True means within memory bounds.

hyperlearn.base.process(f=None, memcheck=None, square=False)[source]¶

[Added 14/11/2018] [Edited 18/11/2018 for speed] Decorator onto HyperLearn functions. Does 2 things: 1. Convert datatypes to appropriate ones 2. Convert matrices to arrays 3. (Optional) checks memory bounds.

f: The function to be decorated memcheck: lambda n,p: ... function or f(n,p)

hyperlearn.linalg module¶

linalg.py¶

Linear Algebra Functions for HyperLearn

hyperlearn.linalg.cho_inv(X, turbo=True)[source]¶

Computes an inverse to the Cholesky Decomposition. [Added 17/11/2018]

X: Upper Triangular Cholesky Factor U. Use cholesky first. turbo: Boolean to use float32, rather than more accurate float64.

hyperlearn.linalg.cho_solve(X, rhs, alpha=None)[source]¶

Given U from a cholesky decompostion and a RHS, find a least squares solution. [Added 15/11/2018]

Parameters:
  • X (Cholesky Factor. Use cholesky first.)
  • alpha (Ridge alpha regularization parameter. Default 1e-6)
  • turbo (Boolean to use float32, rather than more accurate float64.)
Returns:

U
Return type:

Upper triangular cholesky factor (U)
hyperlearn.linalg.cholesky(X, alpha=None)[source]¶

Uses Epsilon Jitter Solver to compute the Cholesky Decomposition until success. Default alpha ridge regularization = 1e-6. [Added 15/11/2018] [Edited 16/11/2018 Numpy is slower. Uses LAPACK only] [Edited 18/11/2018 Uses universal “do_until_success”]

Parameters:
  • X (Matrix to be decomposed. Has to be symmetric.)
  • alpha (Ridge alpha regularization parameter. Default 1e-6)
  • turbo (Boolean to use float32, rather than more accurate float64.)
Returns:

U
Return type:

Upper triangular cholesky factor (U)
hyperlearn.linalg.eig(X, alpha=None, svd=False, n_jobs=1, overwrite=False)[source]¶

[Added 21/11/2018] Returns sorted eigenvalues and eigenvectors from large to small of a general matrix X. Follows SVD convention. Also flips signs of eigenvectors using svd_flip. Uses the Epsilon Jitter Algorithm to guarantee convergence. Allows Ridge Regularization default 1e-6.

According to [Matrix Computations, Third Edition, G. Holub and C. Van Loan, Chapter 5, section 5.4.4, pp 252-253.], QR is better if n >= 5/3p. In Modern Big Data Algorithms, I find QR is better for all n > p.

X: Symmetric Square Matrix. alpha: Ridge alpha regularization parameter. Default 1e-6. svd: Returns sqrt(W) and V.T n_jobs: Whether to use more >= 1 CPU overwrite: Whether to directly alter the original matrix.

hyperlearn.linalg.eigh(X, alpha=None, svd=False, n_jobs=1, overwrite=False)[source]¶

[Added 21/11/2018] Returns sorted eigenvalues and eigenvectors from large to small of a symmetric square matrix X. Follows SVD convention. Also flips signs of eigenvectors using svd_flip. Uses the Epsilon Jitter Algorithm to guarantee convergence. Allows Ridge Regularization default 1e-6.

X: Symmetric Square Matrix. alpha: Ridge alpha regularization parameter. Default 1e-6. svd: Returns sqrt(W) and V.T n_jobs: Whether to use more >= 1 CPU overwrite: Whether to directly alter the original matrix.

hyperlearn.linalg.lu(X, L_only=False, U_only=False, overwrite=False)[source]¶

[Added 16/11/2018] Computes the pivoted LU decomposition of a matrix. Optional to output only L or U components with minimal memory copying.

X: Matrix to be decomposed. Can be retangular. L_only: Output only L. U_only: Output only U. overwrite: Whether to directly alter the original matrix.

hyperlearn.linalg.pinv(X, alpha=None, overwrite=False)[source]¶

[Added 21/11/2018] Returns the inverse of a general Matrix using SVD. Uses the Epsilon Jitter Algorithm to guarantee convergence. Allows Ridge Regularization - default 1e-6.

X: Upper Triangular Cholesky Factor U. Use cholesky. alpha: Ridge alpha regularization parameter. Default 1e-6. overwrite: Whether to directly alter the original matrix.

hyperlearn.linalg.pinvc(X, alpha=None, turbo=True)[source]¶

[Added 17/11/2018] [Edited 18/11/2018 for speed - uses more BLAS] Returns the Pseudoinverse of the matrix X using Cholesky Decomposition. Fastest pinv(X) possible, and uses the Epsilon Jitter Algorithm to guarantee convergence. Allows Ridge Regularization - default 1e-6.

X: Upper Triangular Cholesky Factor U. Use cholesky. alpha: Ridge alpha regularization parameter. Default 1e-6 turbo: Boolean to use float32, rather than more accurate float64.

hyperlearn.linalg.pinvh(X, alpha=None, turbo=True, n_jobs=1)[source]¶

[Added 19/11/2018] Returns the inverse of a square Hermitian Matrix using Cholesky Decomposition. Uses the Epsilon Jitter Algorithm to guarantee convergence. Allows Ridge Regularization - default 1e-6.

X: Upper Triangular Cholesky Factor U. Use cholesky. alpha: Ridge alpha regularization parameter. Default 1e-6 turbo: Boolean to use float32, rather than more accurate float64. n_jobs: Whether to perform multiprocessing.

hyperlearn.linalg.pinvl(X, alpha=None, turbo=True, overwrite=False)[source]¶

[Added 18/11/2018] Computes the pseudoinverse of a square matrix X using LU Decomposition. Notice, it’s much faster to use pinvc (Choleksy Inverse).

X: Matrix to be decomposed. Must be square. alpha: Ridge alpha regularization parameter. Default 1e-6 turbo: Boolean to use float32, rather than more accurate float64. overwrite: Whether to directly alter the original matrix.

hyperlearn.linalg.qr(X, Q_only=False, R_only=False, overwrite=False)[source]¶

[Added 16/11/2018] Computes the reduced economic QR Decomposition of a matrix. Optional to output only Q or R.

X: Matrix to be decomposed. Can be retangular. Q_only: Output only Q. R_only: Output only R. overwrite: Whether to directly alter the original matrix.

hyperlearn.linalg.svd(X, U_decision=False, n_jobs=1, overwrite=False)[source]¶

[Added 19/11/2018] Computes the Singular Value Decomposition of a general matrix providing X = U S VT. Notice VT (V transpose) is returned, and not V. Also, by default, the signs of U and VT are swapped so that VT has the sign of the maximum item as positive.

HyperLearn’s SVD is optimized dramatically due to the findings made in Modern Big Data Algorithms. If p/n >= 0.001, then GESDD is used. Else, GESVD is used. Also, svd(XT) is used if it’s faster, bringing the complexity to O( min(np^2, n^2p) ).

X: Matrix to be decomposed. General matrix. U_decision: Default = False. If True, uses max from U. If None. don’t flip. n_jobs: Whether to use more >= 1 CPU overwrite: Whether to directly alter the original matrix.

function: Function to decorate parallel: If true, sets cache automatically to false

hyperlearn.utils module¶

hyperlearn.utils.add_jitter(X, size, alpha)[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.do_until_success(f, epsilon_f, size, overwrite=False, alpha=None, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.sign_max(X, axis=0, n_jobs=1)[source]¶

[Added 19/11/2018] Returns the sign of the maximum absolute value of an axis of X. Uses BLAS if n_jobs = 1. Uses Numba otherwise.

X: Matrix X to be processed. Must be 2D array. axis: Default = 0. 0 = column-wise. 1 = row-wise. n_jobs: Default = 1. Uses multiple CPUs if n*p > 20,000^2.

hyperlearn.utils.svdCondition(U, S, VT, alpha=None)[source]¶

[Added 21/11/2018] Uses Scipy’s SVD condition number calculation to improve pseudoinverse stability. Uses (1e3, 1e6) * eps(S) * S[0] as the condition number. Everythimg below cond is set to 0.

U: U matrix from SVD S: S diagonal array from SVD VT: VT matrix (V transpose) from SVD alpha: Default = None. Ridge regularization

hyperlearn.utils.svd_flip(U=None, VT=None, U_decision=False, n_jobs=1)[source]¶

[Added 19/11/2018] [Edited 21/11/2018 Uses BLAS] Flips the signs of U and VT from a SVD or eigendecomposition. Default opposite to Sklearn’s U decision. HyperLearn uses the maximum of rows of VT.

U: U matrix from SVD VT: VT matrix (V transpose) from SVD U_decision: Default = False. If True, uses max from U.

hyperlearn.utils.triu(n, p, U)[source]¶
hyperlearn.utils.uint(i, array=True)[source]¶

[Added 14/11/2018] Outputs a small array with the correct dtype that minimises memory usage for storing the maximal number of elements of size i

i: Size of maximal elements you want to store
